choices.text: Patient was Stung by some Insect
Pain may precede or follow Skin Eruptions
There is no associated Muscle Weakness
It is due to Herpes Zoster infection of Spinal Ganglia

questions.text: A 46-year-old man suffered from burning pain on the right side of his chest. The physician noted that there were several watery blebs on the skin in the painful area. On examination, the patient indicated that the pain passed forward over the right seventh intercostal space from the posterior axillary line forward as far as the midline over the sternum. Which of the following statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is due to Herpes Zoster infection of Spinal Ganglia

 

Option D:

 

  • This is classical case due to herpes zoster infection of spinal ganglia
  • Herpes zoster infection presents a classic dermatomal distribution skin lesion.
  • Herpes zoster, commonly known as shingles, is an infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
  • Early Signs are pain, tingling, or itching in a specific area on one side of the body. After a few days, a painful rash appears, usually as a single stripe of blisters that wraps around either the left or right side of the torso. It can also occur around one eye or on one side of the neck or face.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patient was stung by some insect- in this case dermatome involvement not seen. Hence it is not the answer.

 

Option B. Pain may precede or follow skin eruptions- it is not seen in case of herpes infection usually. Hence it is not the answer.

 

Option C. There is no associated muscle weakness- There is no relation of muscle weakness with herpes infection. Hence it is also not the answer.

 

Educational objective:

 

“Painful vesicular eruption along the dermatome” is classical presentation of herpes infection. 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 944

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-3, C-5, D-2

 

Correct matching is.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Subcostal vessels and nerve run along the inferior border of the 12th rib. They are not directly associated with any of the specific diaphragmatic openings but are related to the area just below the ribcage They pass behind the lateral arcuate ligament.
  2. The sympathetic trunk runs vertically along the vertebral column. It is located posteriorly in the abdomen and is not directly associated with the diaphragmatic openings but lies behind the medial arcuate ligament.
  3. Superior epigastric vessels are continuations of the internal thoracic (mammary) artery and vein. They travel through the space of Larrey, which is a gap between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm on either side.
  4. The thoracic duct is the main lymphatic duct of the body. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm at the level of T12.
  5. The phrenic nerve provides the main motor supply to the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve enters the thoracic cavity and passes through the caval opening (IVC opening) in the diaphragm at the level of T8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minor openings in Diaphragm:

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 180

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. She is hemodynamically stable but complains of chest pain. A chest x-ray is ordered to evaluate for potential rib fractures. The physician palpates a bony landmark to identify the second rib before counting the ribs on the x-ray. Which of the following landmarks corresponds to the attachment of the second rib?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sternal Angle of Louis

 

Option B:

 

  • The Sternal angle, also known as the angle of Louis, is a palpable bony landmark formed by the articulation of the manubrium and the body of the sternum. It corresponds to the level of the second rib's attachment to the sternum.
  • This landmark is clinically significant as it is used as a reference point for counting ribs and intercostal spaces in chest examinations and imaging.

 

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. The Xiphoid process is the inferior, cartilaginous portion of the sternum and does not correspond to the attachment of the second rib.

 

Option C. The Costal margin is the lower border of the rib cage formed by the costal cartilages of the seventh to tenth ribs and is not related to the second rib.

 

Option D. The Inferior border of the scapula, when the arms are at the sides, is typically at the level of the seventh or eighth rib and not the second rib.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Sternal angle of Louis corresponds to the level of the second rib's attachment to the sternum and is the correct answer.
  • Identify the sternal angle of Louis as the anatomical landmark that corresponds to the attachment of the second rib to the sternum, which is useful for orientation during chest examinations and interpreting chest x-rays.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 293.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to persistent respiratory distress and feeding difficulties since birth. The baby appears to have labored breathing, and the parents report that he frequently vomits after feeds. On physical examination, the infant is tachypneic with retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray shows abdominal contents in the left thoracic cavity, confirming the diagnosis of a diaphragmatic hernia.  Which of the following structure passes through the marked opening in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oesophagus

 

Option B:

 

  • This is a case of diaphragmatic hernia through marked opening.
  • Pointed opening is for the oesophagus that lies opposite the T10 vertebra.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IVC opening is located opposite the T8 vertebra.

 

Option C. Aortic opening lies opposite T10.

 

Option D. Greater and lesser splanchnic nerves pierce each crus.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Oesophageal branches of left gastric vessels, anterior and posterior vagal trunks pass through esophageal opening.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 211

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with numbness and a tingling sensation in the medial aspect of her upper arm and axilla. She reports no history of trauma or surgery in the area. Physical examination reveals a loss of sensation in the corresponding region without any motor deficits. This sensory loss pattern is most likely associated with a branch of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Second Intercostal Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The intercostobrachial nerve, a sensory nerve, typically arises from the second intercostal nerve.
  • It extends into the axillary region, supplying sensation to the upper medial aspect of the arm and the axilla.
  • This nerve can be impacted during surgical procedures such as axillary lymph node dissection in breast cancer surgery, leading to sensory loss or neuropathic pain in its distribution area.
  • The preservation of the intercostobrachial nerve during surgery is often emphasized to reduce postoperative sensory deficits and improve patient quality of life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. First intercostal nerve- It gives sensory innervation along medial border of forearm.

 

Option C. Third intercostal nerve- It gives sensory innervation above the nipple

 

Option D. Upper trunk of brachial plexus- It is formed by C5 & C6 Roots

 

Above all are not related to sensory nerve supply along medial aspect of upper arm and axilla as mentioned in question hence these are not the answer.

 

Educational objective:

 

Intercostobrachial nerve is the undivided lateral cutaneous branch of ventral ramus of T2.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 211

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracic Duct

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Right phrenic nerve branches pass through IVC opening, left phrenic nerve pierces left cupola.

 

Option C. IVC opening lies opposite the T8 vertebral level in the central tendon.

 

Option D. Least splanchnic nerve passes behind the medial arcuate ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic opening lies opposite the T12 vertebra. It transmits aorta, thoracic duct, and sometimes azygos vein.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and lower limb, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 179

questions.text: Following are the branches of marked structure, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior intercostal artery

 

Option B:

 

  • Posterior intercostal artery of the upper two spaces arises from the superior intercostal artery and the rest of the spaces arise from descending aorta.

 

 

  • The pointed structure in the given image is internal thoracic artery.

 

 

  • The internal thoracic artery, previously known as the internal mammary artery, is a major artery in the thorax (chest) that plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the chest wall and breasts.
  • It arises from the subclavian artery and descends along the inside of the chest wall.
  • Its branches are enumerated below:
    1. Anterior Intercostal Arteries
    2. Pericardio phrenic Artery
    3. Musculo phrenic Artery
    4. Superior Epigastric Artery
    5. Mediastinal Branches
    6. Thymic Branches
    7. Perforating Branches
       
  • This artery is significant not only for its role in supplying blood to the thoracic structures but also as a source for coronary artery bypass grafts in cardiac surgery, given its size, accessibility, and the adequacy of its blood flow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior intercostal arteries are two in number in each space. They are absent in the lower two spaces.

 

Option C. Internal thoracic artery terminates into superior epigastric and musculophrenic arteries in 6th intercostal space.

 

Option D. 7th to 9th spaces anterior intercostal arteries arise from musculophrenic arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior intercostal artery of the upper two spaces arises from the superior intercostal artery and the rest of the spaces arise from descending aorta.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 214

choices.text: Medial part of Diaphragmatic Pleura

questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Costal pleura

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is the phrenic nerve.
  • Phrenic nerve doesn’t supply the costal pleura.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The phrenic nerve is the primary nerve supply for the diaphragm, providing both motor and sensory innervation. "C3, C4, and C5 keep the diaphragm alive" is a mnemonic often used to remember the spinal roots of the phrenic nerve.

 

Option B. The phrenic nerve provides sensory innervation to the mediastinal pleura.

 

Option D. The phrenic nerve provides sensory innervation to the central or medial part of the diaphragmatic pleura. However, the peripheral part of the diaphragmatic receives sensory innervation from the lower six intercostal nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Costal pleura: This part is not primarily supplied by the phrenic nerve for sensation. Instead, it receives sensory innervation from the intercostal nerves.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 225

choices.text: A cut was seen about 3 cm wide over the left clavicle
Auscultation revealed diminished breath sounds over the left hemithorax
The left upper limb was lying stationary on the table, and active movement of the small muscles of the left hand was absent
The patient was insensitive to pin prick along the lateral side of the left arm, forearm, and hand

questions.text: A 40-year-old male indulged in a quarrel with his friend who refused to accept his views regarding their business loss. In a moment of temper, he plunged a knife at his friend, striking his anterior neck over the left clavicle. The friend collapsed on the floor, bleeding profusely from the wound. On examination in the emergency department of the hospital, the following conditions were found except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The patient was insensitive to pin prick along the lateral side of the left arm, forearm, and hand

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case the knife had struck the lower trunk of brachial plexus as well as the left dome of the cervical pleura.
  • Loss of skin sensation that occurred in the C8 and T1 dermatomes on the medial, not on the lateral, side of the left forearm and hand (Ulnar Nerve).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A cut is possible over the left clavicle in case of injury by knife over the clavicle.

 

Option B. Left pneumothorax with left-sided diminished breath sounds and a deflection of the trachea to the left as a result of injury to the apex of the left lung.

 

Option C. Loss of movement of the small muscles of the left hand especially those supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The knife had struck the lower trunk of brachial plexus which involves C8 & T1 dermatome & ulnar nerve.  Loss of skin sensation is due to this C8 and T1 dermatomes damage on the medial side of the left forearm and hand (ulnar nerve).

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 956

choices.text: The needle had penetrated too deeply and pierced the lung.
The needle was inserted too close to the lower border of the eighth rib and damaged the eighth intercostal nerve
The needle was inserted too low down in the intercostal space
The needle had penetrated the eighth rib

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of left-sided pleurisy with pneumonia. Pleurocentesis was planned. The resident inserted the needle close to the lower border of the eighth rib in the anterior axillary line. The next morning, he was surprised to hear that the patient had complained of altered skin sensation extending from the point where the needle was inserted downward and forward to the midline of the abdominal wall above the umbilicus. The altered skin sensation in this patient after the needle thoracostomy could be explained by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The needle was inserted too close to the lower border of the eighth rib and damaged the eighth intercostal nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The needle was inserted too close to the lower border of the eighth rib and damaged the eighth intercostal nerve
  • The costal groove that contains the neurovascular bundle is situated on the inner aspect close to the lower border of the rib.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The needle had penetrated too deeply and pierced the lung; In this condition more complication involving the lung symptoms will be seen.

 

Option C. The needle was inserted too low down in the intercostal space; In question given that the resident inserted the needle close to the lower border of the eighth rib in the anterior axillary line. Hence this option is not the answer.

 

Option D. The needle had penetrated the eighth rib; Again this option could not be the answer as in question already told that the resident inserted the needle close to the lower border of the eighth rib in the anterior axillary line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspiration of any fluid from the pleural cavity is called Paracentesis Thoracis. It is usually done in the eighth intercostal space in the mid axillary line.
  • The needle is passed through the lower part of the space to avoid injury to the principal neurovascular bundle, i.e. Vein, Artery and Nerve (VAN).

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 943, BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 8th Edition, Volume 1, Page no- 261

questions.text: From which vessel do the upper two posterior intercostal arteries originate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior Intercostal Artery

 

Option B:

 

  • Posterior intercostal artery of the upper two spaces arise from the superior intercostal artery and the rest of the spaces arise from descending aorta.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aorta gives 3rd to 11th posterior ICA not upper 2.

 

Option C. Internal mammary artery is branch of subclavian artery. It has no relation with Posterior ICA.

 

Option D. There is usually one bronchial artery on the right, which arises from the third posterior intercostal artery or from the upper left bronchial artery. The left bronchial arteries usually number two and arise from the descending thoracic aorta inferior to the origin of the third posterior intercostal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the upper two spaces, posterior intercostal arteries arise from superior intercostal arteries.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 215

questions.text: Which of the following is a synchondrosis joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D

 

The marked structure in the given image are

 

  1. Acromioclavicular Joint
  2. Manubriosternal Joint
  3. Costochondral Joint
  4. Chondrosternal Joint
  • Among given options- Costochondral joint & Chondrosternal joint are synchondrosis joint.
  • A synchondrosis joint is a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage.
  • This type of joint is typically found in areas where growth occurs, allowing for bone lengthening.
  • A classic example is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate) in long bones, where the plate of hyaline cartilage between the epiphysis and diaphysis enables bone growth during childhood and adolescence.
  • Another example is the joint between the first rib and the manubrium of the sternum.
  • Synchondroses are temporary joints, often replaced by bone as a person ages and growth completes, resulting in a synostosis, or a complete bony fusion of the joint.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acromioclavicular joint is a plane synovial joint.

 

Option B. Manubriosternal joint, Xiphisternal joint is secondary cartilaginous/symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. 2nd to 6th chondrosternal joints are plane synovial joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

First chondrosternal joint, D- Costochondral joint are primary cartilaginous joints/synchondrosis

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 197

choices.text: Manubrium of the Sternum
Body of the Sternum
Sternal Angle of Louis

questions.text: During a clinical anatomy class, medical students are reviewing the attachments of the ribs to the sternum. One student asks about the anatomical landmarks related to the first rib. Which of the following structures is most closely associated with the attachment of the first rib?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manubrium of the Sternum

 

Option A:

 

  • The first rib attaches to the manubrium of the sternum. This attachment is significant as the first rib is typically not visible on a standard chest X-ray due to its high position and overlap with other structures.

 

 

 

Explanation:


Option B. The Body of the sternum is the longest part of the sternum and articulates with the ribs from the second to the seventh rib, but not the first rib.


Option C. The Xiphoid process is the smallest and most inferior part of the sternum and does not articulate directly with any ribs.


Option D. The Sternal angle of Louis is the joint formed by the articulation of the manubrium and the body of the sternum and corresponds to the second rib's attachment, not the first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Manubrium of the sternum is the correct answer. It is the upper part of the sternum and articulates with the first rib and the clavicle.
  • Recognize that the first rib attaches to the manubrium of the sternum, distinguishing it from the other ribs which attach to the body of the sternum or not at all (in the case of the xiphoid process).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 202.

choices.text: Transverse Process of the Seventh Cervical Vertebra
Body of the Sternum
Manubrium of the Sternum

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of tingling and numbness in his right arm. The physician suspects thoracic outlet syndrome and decides to evaluate the anatomical structures in the region. Which of the following structures is most closely associated with the attachment of the first rib?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transverse process of the seventh cervical vertebra

 

Option A:

 

  • The first rib has a unique anatomical position and attaches posteriorly to the transverse process of the seventh cervical vertebra (C7) and anteriorly to the manubrium of the sternum.
  • This anatomical relationship is important in the context of thoracic outlet syndrome, where compression of neurovascular structures can occur in the region between the first rib and the clavicle.

 

 

Explanation:


Option B. The Body of the sternum does not articulate with the first rib. It articulates with the second to the seventh ribs.


Option C. The Manubrium of the sternum is the anterior attachment of the first rib, making it a close but not the most accurate choice for this question.

 

Option D. The Xiphoid process is the most inferior portion of the sternum and does not articulate with the ribs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Transverse process of the seventh cervical vertebra is the correct answer as it is the posterior attachment site of the first rib.

 

 

 

  • Recognize that the first rib attaches posteriorly to the transverse process of the seventh cervical vertebra and anteriorly to the manubrium of the sternum, which is relevant in understanding the anatomical basis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 202.

choices.text: Ribs 1-7, Directly Articulating with the Sternum via their own Costal Cartilages
Ribs 8-10, connecting to the Sternum via the Costal Cartilage of the Rib Above
Ribs 11-12, not Articulating with the Aternum at all
Ribs 5-9, Articulating indirectly with the Sternum via a Common Costal Cartilage

questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomy of the thoracic cage and learns about the classification of ribs into true, false, and floating ribs. Which of the following best describes the true ribs?
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ribs 1-7, Directly Articulating with the Sternum via their own Costal Cartilages.

 

Option A:

 

  • True ribs are defined by their direct articulation with the sternum via their own costal cartilages. This direct attachment allows for a more rigid support for the thoracic cage, which is essential for the protection of vital thoracic organs.

 

 

 

Explanation:


Option B. Ribs 8-10 are known as false ribs. They do not directly connect to the sternum but are connected to the costal cartilage of the rib above and ultimately to the sternum.


Option C. Ribs 11-12 are referred to as floating ribs because they do not have any anterior attachment to the sternum or to the costal cartilages of the ribs above.


Option D. Ribs 5-9 do not fit the description of any specific category of ribs. The first seven are true ribs, the next three are false ribs, and the last two are floating ribs.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Ribs 1-7 are the true ribs and they directly articulate with the sternum via their own costal cartilages, making this statement correct.
  • Identify that true ribs (ribs 1-7) directly articulate with the sternum via their own costal cartilages, distinguishing them from false ribs (ribs 8-10) and floating ribs (ribs 11-12).

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 200.
